journal-meta.journal-title: Transactions of the Institute of Measurement and Control

title-group.article-title: Characteristic ratio assignment in fractional order systems (case 0 < v ≤ 0.5)

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Electrical Engineering, Science and Research Branch, Islamic Azad University, Tehran, Iran
2Advanced Control System Lab, Electrical Engineering Department, Sharif University of Technology, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Mohammad Haeri, Advanced Control System Lab, Electrical Engineering Department, Sharif University of Technology, Azadi Ave., Tehran, Iran. Email: haeri@sina.sharif.edu

abstract.p: Five different approaches are presented to assign characteristic ratios for commensurate fractional order systems having order in (0,0.5]. Through the indirect methods, a closed-loop or plant transfer function is converted to a commensurate order one with an order greater than 0.5 so that the previously designed CRA method by the authors is applicable. The first method among the proposed direct ones is based on increasing the order of the desired closed-loop transfer function that allows the employment of positive characteristic ratios. In the second method the closed-loop response is sped up by augmenting an appropriate zero. The final method uses negative characteristic ratios to reach the goal. Computer simulations are provided to show the performance of the mentioned methods in a comparative study.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Shaping the transient response is generally among the main goals in a control design approach. Designing a controller to have a non-overshooting step response is performed by properly arranging zeros and poles of the closed-loop transfer function (Darbha, 2003; Deodhare and Vidyasagar, 1990; Graham and Lathrop, 1953; Jin and Kim, 2008; Moore and Bhattacharya, 1990; Phillips and Seborg, 1988). The concurrent adjustment of time and amplitude specifications is so difficult that it is generally confined to systems with dominant poles only (Wang et al., 2009; Astrom and Hagglund, 1995). To present methods through them, one could adjust these specifications independently, which would be of great importance. The CRA method attempts to assign characteristic ratios to have a step response with maximally limited overshoot. The generalized time constant is then adjusted so that the desired closed-loop speed is achieved. In other words, systems with the same characteristic ratios would have similar damping in their step responses, while the rise and settling times would be proportional to their generalized time constants.

The first work about CRA was conducted by Kessler (1960). Naslin (1969) and Manabe (1998) presented other CRA-based design methods to control transient response of minimum phase systems. Several new methods have been presented in the last decade (Kim et al., 2003; Tavazoei and Haeri, 2005, 2010).

All of these methods are confined to systems that could be described by ordinary differential equations. Nowadays scientists are interested in a new type of model called fractional order systems, which use non-integer differentiators (Miller and Ross, 1993; Podlubny, 1999; Sabatier et al., 2007). It is claimed that these models could better represent industrial processes, especially those processes that include diffusion and viscoelasticity phenomena (Benchella et al., 2006; Meral et al., 2010; Spasic and Lazarevic, 2005; Sun et al., 2009). The growth of using such models necessitates generalizing ordinary control strategies to control such complicated systems as well. For example, one of the famous methods in this regard is the fractional order PID controller, which is a generalization of the ordinary PID with non-integer differentiators and integrators (Biswas et al., 2009; Lee and Chang, 2010; Luo et al., 2010; Merrikh-Bayat and Karimimi-Ghartemani, 2010; Tabatabei and Haeri, 2010b; Valerio and Costa, 2006).

Few works have been published about the transient response control of fractional order systems. In Tavazoei and Bahavarnia (2010), some sufficient conditions for the existence of the overshoot in the step response of a fractional order system have been presented. The main recent work in this field is a CRA method proposed for fractional order systems with a commensurate order in the range (0.5,1] (Tabatabaei and Haeri, 2010a). The presented method considers a periodic pattern for the characteristic ratios to attain a specified overshoot for the step response of such systems.

A lot of fractional order systems could be described by a commensurate order transfer function with a commensurate order smaller than 0.5. For example, a fractional order system with derivative orders 0.7, 0.4 and 0.3 could be considered as a commensurate order transfer function with a commensurate order 0.1. In contrast, some physical plants could be only described with a commensurate order 0.5, and their performance could not be improved through the early proposed CRA methods (Tabatabaei and Haeri, 2010a).

In this paper we complete the proposed method by assigning the characteristic ratios for fractional order systems with a commensurate order in the range (0,0.5]. Five different methods are proposed here. Two of them are indirect methods that employ the proposed approach in Tabatabaei and Haeri (2010a). This is accomplished by either changing the desired closed-loop transfer function to a commensurate order one with an order belonging to (0.5,1] or approximating the plant transfer function with a fractional order model with a commensurate order in the range of (0.5,1]. In the first direct design method, a structure with two free parameters is presented to find proper characteristic ratios. In the second direct method, the characteristic ratios are determined by considering an adjustable zero for the desired closed-loop system. In the third direct method, a characteristic equation with some negative coefficients is proposed for the desired closed-loop system.

This paper has been organized as follows: In Section 2, definitions of characteristic ratio and generalized time constant in commensurate fractional order systems are presented. Five newly presented CRA-based design methods are introduced in Section 3. The performance of these methods in control of commensurate order systems are verified through an example in Section 4. Conclusions and future perspectives are given in Section 5.

sec.title: Some necessary preliminaries
sec.p: Fractional calculus as a mathematical topic initiated from 17th century deals with the fractional order operators. A fractional order derivative, a generalization of the ordinary derivative, allows for more flexibility in modeling and controlling of dynamic systems (Podlubny, 1999; Sabatier et al., 2007). Calculating a non-integer derivative of a variable in time t is not possible without the value of this variable from −∞ to t (Podlubny, 1999). Thus, fractional order systems that include this operator are the special case of infinite-dimensional systems. When the derivative orders of a fractional order system are integer multiples of a real number, the system is called a commensurate fractional order system (Podlubny, 1999). The transfer function of a linear time invariant commensurate fractional order system with commensurate order v has the following form

The CRA method is an approach to control the transient response of the system in equation (1) (Tabatabaei and Haeri, 2010a). In this method the desired closed-loop transfer function is determined according to the desired step response. This transfer function is an all-pole commensurate order one as follows

The denominator coefficients are calculated to have a step response with a maximum allowable overshoot (say 2%) and a desired rise or settling time. In this regard, the characteristic ratios (αk,k=1,…,n−1) and the generalized time constant (τ) are defined as follows

The characteristic ratios could specify the damping in the transient step response. The time response speed could be adjusted using the generalized time constant independently. This means that in systems with the same characteristic ratios, the generalized time constant could scale the step responses proportionally.
The denominator coefficients in terms of the characteristic ratios and generalized time constant could be calculated as
When v belongs to (0.5,1], the following relation for the characteristic ratios could result in a step response with maximum 2% overshoot for all values of n (Tabatabaei and Haeri, 2010a)

With this assignment of the characteristic ratios, the step response of the system in equation (2) is kept unchanged for n≥5. So this method could be used to design the desired closed-loop transfer function with any order properly. Having the desired closed-loop system, a lot of control strategies, such as pole placement method, RST control structure and other model matching methods, could be employed to adjust the control parameters (Moore and Silverman, 1972; Emre and Silverman, 1980).
To complete the proposed method, this paper presents CRA methods for systems with the commensurate order belonging to (0,0.5].

sec.title: Proposed CRA based methods for 0 < v ≤ 0.5
sec.p: In Tabatabaei and Haeri (2010a), it is shown that the step response of the system in equation (2) could not have overshoot when nv≤1. Since in the CRA method a minimum overshoot is preferred, in this section some new CRA patterns are introduced to attain minimum overshoot step responses.
Consider an all-pole commensurate fractional order system in the form of equation (2) where 0<v≤0.5. Five different methods are proposed here to determine the characteristic ratios in this case.

The first method is an indirect one in which the closed-loop transfer function is converted to a fractional order system with commensurate order in (0.5,1]. This could be achieved by tuning control parameters to equate some coefficients in the desired closed-loop transfer function to zero. The remaining coefficients are determined based on the proposed algorithm in Tabatabaei and Haeri (2010a). The only deficiency of this algorithm is that the order of the controller would be increased, which increases the implementation cost.

The second approach assigns characteristic ratios directly when nv>1. In this case, the order of the desired transfer function is obtained in accordance to the commensurate order. Owing to the existence of two degrees of freedom in the obtained relation, the adjustment of the characteristic ratios is not straightforward.

In the third method, a proper zero is added to the desired transfer function to reach a maximum allowable overshoot in the system step response. The location of the zero is adjusted so that the time scaling property is retained.

The fourth method utilizes characteristic ratios with both positive and negative signs to reach the desired overshoot. In the final method, an appropriate approximation for the plant transfer function is proposed, which could help to indirectly assign the characteristic ratios.

sec.title: The CRA method with changing the commensurate order
sec.p: As an indirect method, this one attempts to assign characteristic ratios using the given relation in equation (5). Here, the closed-loop transfer function with a commensurate order in the range of (0,0.5] is converted to one with a commensurate order in the range of (0.5,1]. The following lemma helps to understand the proposed design method.

list-item.p: Lemma 1: For a fractional order system with commensurate order v(0<v≤0.5), the closed-loop system could be written as a fractional order transfer function with commensurate order v1(0.5<v1≤1) by setting some coefficients of the closed-loop transfer function with commensurate order v to zero. The relation between v1 and v would be as follows

sec.p: where m is an integer number and is determined as follows
where [x] is the integer part of the real number x.

As an example, the corresponding value for v=0.3 is v1=0.6. Therefore, for a desired closed-loop system with a pseudo-second-order transfer function, the corresponding coefficients of the terms with orders 0.3 and 0.9 are equated to zero by properly choosing the control parameters. In other words, only terms with orders 1.2, 0.6 and 0 would have non-zero coefficients that form a closed-loop transfer function with commensurate order v1=0.6 and therefore could be determined using the proposed algorithm in Tabatabaei and Haeri (2010a). The following example clarifies the design approach:

list-item.p: Example 1. Consider a plant with the following transfer function

sec.p: To obtain step responses of the fractional order systems, the Fractional Order Transfer Function (FOTF) toolbox introduced by Chen et al. (2009) has been employed. This MATLAB toolbox utilizes a numerical approach based on the Grunwald–Letnikov definition of the fractional order derivative (Podlubny, 1999; Chen et al., 2009). Figure 1 shows the unit step response of the plant. The rise time of the response is 17.92 seconds. The control goal is to have a transient step response with the maximum 2% overshoot and 6 seconds rise time.

caption.p: The unit step response for system in (8).

sec.p: Based on equations (6) and (7), the desired closed-loop transfer function would be commensurate with v1=0.8 and order n=2. Therefore, the characteristic ratio can be calculated according to equation (5) as α=0.6149.

The initial choice for the generalized time constant is taken as τi=4seconds. This choice results in a step response with 11.75 seconds rise time. According to the time scaling property, the final generalized time constant is determined as τf=6×4/11.75=2.0426seconds. Figure 2 compares the initial design with the final one.

caption.p: The initial and final design for Example 1.

sec.p: The desired closed-loop transfer function is calculated as

To design a controller for system in equation (8) in order to obtain the closed-loop system in equation (9), one may consider an RST control structure (Figure 3). A proper choice for the polynomials of the controller would be as follows

caption.p: The RST control structure.

sec.p: Considering these polynomials, transfer function of the closed-loop system is
Matching the transfer functions in equations (9) and (11) determines the control parameters as r0=0,r1=22.16,r2=−10.19,r3=5.09,s1=−44.33,t0=1. Figure 4 shows the control signal.

caption.p: The control signal for system in Example 1.

sec.title: The CRA method with nv > 1
sec.p: This approach is a direct method. However, to have overshoot in the system step response, the order of the desired closed-loop transfer function is selected such that nv>1. The minimum value for n is considered as n=[v−1]+1. In other words, when v belongs to ((n+1)−1,n−1), an all-pole commensurate order transfer function with an order at least n+1 is considered. For example when 3−1<v<2−1, the transfer function would be as follows

To have an overshoot free step response, the frequency response magnitude of this system should be a monotonically decreasing function (Chestnut and Mayer, 1959). The squared magnitude of the frequency response is calculated as

When all denominator coefficients in equation (13) are nonnegative, this function will be monotonically decreasing. Some of these coefficients are always positive. Therefore only the following inequalities should be satisfied:

Assuming positive coefficients for the system, equation (12) satisfies inequalities a1 and a3. Thus, only inequality a2 should be verified. This inequality could be rewritten in terms of characteristic ratios as follows
which could be always satisfied when the product of the characteristic ratios are selected as α1α2=3. This means that
where λ is an arbitrary real number.
For 4−1<v<3−1, the transfer function would have the following form
Performing the same procedure as in the case n=3 ends up to the satisfactions of the following inequalities
These inequalities are fulfilled when the characteristic ratios are assigned as
The same behavior could be traced for larger values of n as well. Therefore, the following theorem is proposed.
Theorem 1. The system in equation (2) with n−1<v<(n−1)−1 will not have overshoot in its step response if its characteristic ratios are assigned as follows
where λ is a real number and could be considered as a degree of freedom.
Proof: Based on the procedure explained for cases n=3 and n=4, proof would be trivial.

When a non-overshooting step response is required, equation (20) is adequate to determine the characteristic ratios. To satisfy inequalities in equations (15) and (18), the product of the successive characteristic ratios in the pattern of equation (20) is considered as 3. The contravention of the mentioned inequalities could result in a minimum overshoot step response. This could be achieved when the product of the successive characteristic ratios is considered smaller than 3 (according to the value of the commensurate order). However, when a transient response with minimum overshoot is desired, one may use the following
where 0<β≤1.

Both free parameters of equation (21) (i.e. λ and β) have to be adjusted simultaneously to attain a predefined overshoot. However, it would be difficult (if not impossible) to find a same relation between λ and β for all values of n in order to have a specific overshoot level. The following example illustrates the point.

Example 2. Let assume v=0.45 in equation (2). To have a non-overshooting step response, one may employ equation (20) with an arbitrary value for λ (say 0.6). Figure 5 shows the unit step responses of the system with two values of n (n=3,10) and the generalized time constant τ=0.1seconds. These responses are identical and have no overshoot.

caption.p: The unit step response of system (2) (v = 0.45, β=1, n = 3,10).

sec.p: To have a step response with 2% overshoot, one may use the relation in equation (21). The appropriate value for β is found by trial and error as β=0.004 for the case n=3. Figure 6 shows the unit step responses of the system with two different values of the generalized time constant (τ=0.5,1). These responses are time-scaled versions of each other with scaling factor 2. The overshoot is kept fixed (2%) in either case. Figure 7 shows the unit step response of the same system with β=0.004, τ=0.5seconds and n=4. In this case the overshoot is about 48% and is completely different from the one obtained for n=3. In other words, to have a same level of overshoot for different n, β has to be adjusted individually.

caption.p: The unit step response of system (2) (v = 0.45, β=0.004, τ=0.5,1).
The unit step response of system (2) (v = 0.45, β=0.004, τ=0.5, n = 4).

sec.title: The CRA method with an added zero
sec.p: The third method is based on adding a zero to the all-pole commensurate order system in equation (2). By this augmentation it would be possible to get overshoot in the system step response with positive characteristic ratios even in the case nv<1. However, two main privileges of CRA methods, i.e. the time scaling and independency of the time and amplitude specifications, would be preserved only if one chooses the zero location properly.
To present the method, we begin with small values of n. Let us consider the system in equation (2) for n=2. Adding a zero in this case results in the following transfer function
The squared magnitude of the frequency response for the system in equation (22) is determined as

This function will be monotonically decreasing if |G(jω1)|2>|G(jω2)|2 for every ω1<ω2. After some calculations and disregarding the obvious inequalities, the following conditions are required for |G(jω)|2 to be a monotonically decreasing function:

To have overshoot in the step response of the system, these conditions should not be satisfied all to gather while parameters ai and b are positive. To reach the goal, one option is to violate the first two conditions and use the equality in the third one. The following choice for the characteristic ratio and the parameter b would do the job:
The level of overshoot is adjustable by the proper choice of parameter γ.
For n=3 the closed-loop system would have the following transfer function:
The squared magnitude of the frequency response in this case becomes
To have a monotonically decreasing function, the following inequalities should be held

To have overshoot in the step response, it is necessary not to have all these conditions be satisfied. The first three conditions are exactly same as those in equation (24). The fourth condition (d4) is always satisfied (note that 0<v≤0.5 and all parameters ai and b are positive). Our choice is to violate the second condition (in this case the first condition will be violated as well) and to satisfy conditions d3 and d5. To do so, b and α1 are selected as in the previous case. To satisfy condition d5, α1α2 is chosen to be 3 (this value is selected to have the same pattern for multiplication of successive characteristic ratios). Again one can adjust the overshoot level by adjusting parameter γ:
Continuing the same procedure for larger values of n results in the following theorem.
Theorem 2. Consider a commensurate fractional order system with the following transfer function
where v belongs to (0,0.5]. To have a desired overshoot level in the step response of this system, the characteristic ratios and zero position should be assigned using the following pattern
The free parameter (γ) of equation (31) is tuned to have a predesigned overshoot in the transient response.
Proof: Based on procedure explained for cases n=2 and n=3, proof would be trivial.
Table 1 shows values of γ for obtaining 2% overshoot in the step response of system equation (30) for each value of v and all values of n.

caption.p: The appropriate values of γ for different values of v.

sec.p: The following theorem shows that adding zero in accordance with equation (31) has no effect on the separation of time and amplitude specifications.

Theorem 3. When in equation (30) b is selected as γa1 where γ>1, then with the definition given for the characteristic ratios and the generalized time constant in equation (3), the change in the step response speed could be performed only by adjusting the generalized time constant.
Proof. Let us assume two different generalized time constants as τ1 and τ2. According to equation (4), the transfer function of the system in equation (31) could be rewritten as
for the generalized time constant τ1 and
for the generalized time constant τ2.

It can be easily shown that the step responses of systems in equations (32) and (33) are time-scaled versions of one another with the scaling factor τ1/τ2. To prove this, it is enough to substitute s by (τ2/τ1)s in the equation (33)
Thus, the transfer function in equation (33) is obtained.
In fact, the zero location is varied proportional to the generalized time constant so that the overshoot in the step response has been kept unchanged.
The next example illustrates the application of the third proposed method in assigning the characteristic ratios.

Example 3. Consider equation (30) with n=2, v=0.35. Figure 8 shows the unit step response of this system with two different values of the generalized time constant (τ=0.2,0.8) and γ=1.1. The overshoot for these responses is 1.97%, which is smaller than the maximum allowable overshoot (2%). The corresponding rise times are 0.007 and 0.0278 seconds. These values confirm the accuracy of the Theorem 3.

caption.p: The unit step response for system (30) for (v = 0.35, γ=1.1 and τ=0.2,0.8).

sec.title: The CRA method with negative characteristicratios
sec.p: In this method, negative characteristic ratios are employed to achieve a minimum overshoot in the step response. When the denominator coefficients of the transfer function in equation (2) are negative, the given definitions for characteristic ratios and generalized time constant in equation (3) could not be applicable anymore. In this case, the following modified definitions are utilized:

According to definitions in equation (35), the characteristic ratios could have negative values, but the generalized time constant is always positive. Based on the given definitions in equation (35), the relation in equation (4) is modified as follows:
This means that the denominator coefficients could not be uniquely determined in terms of the defined characteristic ratios and the generalized time constant.
To find a general form for the characteristic ratios, start with n=2. The following transfer function is considered:
The squared magnitude of the frequency response of the system is calculated as
This function will be monotonically decreasing if the following inequalities are satisfied; therefore, there will be no overshoot in the step response of the system in equation (37):

Considering positive coefficients, all three conditions in equation (39) are fulfilled. Thus, to have a step response with a minimum overshoot, it would be necessary to violate at least one of these conditions. This can happen by selecting negative value for coefficient a1. This selection will result in a positive characteristic ratio when a0 and a2 have positive values. Then, the following pattern is proposed to reach a step response with a predefined overshoot:
where μ is an adjustable parameter that can be tuned to reach a desired overshoot. This parameter is a function of the commensurate order (v).

Now let us consider the case n=3 for which the transfer function is given in equation (12). The squared magnitude of this transfer function frequency response is given in equation (13). The sufficient conditions to have a non-overshooting step response are

To attain a step response with minimum overshoot, it would be necessary to violate at least one of the given conditions in equation (41). Considering 0<v≤0.5, the following choice violates at least conditions f3 and f5:
Again μ is used to tune the overshoot level in the step response. Based on the proposed pattern in equation (42), the value of a1 is negative, and the other coefficients are positive.
Continuing the same procedure for other values of n, we propose the following pattern for the characteristic ratios:
The coefficients of the characteristic equation are determined as
The proposed pattern for the coefficients consists of one negative value (a1) followed by three successive positive values (a2, a3, and a4) and is repeated periodically.
Table 2 shows the appropriate values of μ for some values of v. These values are calculated to reach a maximum 2% overshoot in the step response of the system for all values of n.

caption.p: The appropriate values of μ for some values of v.

sec.p: The following example illustrates how negative coefficients can be used to obtain a desired step response.
Example 4. Suppose n=3 and v=0.5. Considering μ=0.004 and τ=0.1seconds, the following transfer function is obtained:
The unit step response of system (45) is given in Figure 9. The overshoot is about 1.75%, which is very close to the desired one (2%).

caption.p: The unit step response for system in (45).

sec.title: The CRA method based on approximatingmodel
sec.p: In this approach, the plant transfer function is approximated by a commensurate transfer function with a commensurate order in the range of (0.5,1]. This is done using either numerical (optimization) or analytical (model reduction) methods. Now for the approximated model, one may use the proposed pattern in equation (5) to build the desired closed-loop characteristic equation.
Consider the following transfer function for a plant:
where m<n and 0<v≤0.5. This plant could be approximated by the following transfer function:
where m^<n^ and 0.5<v^≤1. To match the steady-state gains, the following relation has to be satisfied:
However, these two transfer functions have the same high-frequency specifications when the following relation is satisfied as well:
The coefficients of the transfer function in equation (47) are calculated so that the following cost function is minimized:

The coincident frequencies (ωi) in equation (50) are selected to cover an interesting range of frequencies for the original plant in equation (46) (N is the number of coincident frequencies). The unknown parameters could be determined by a constrained optimization technique. This method is applicable even for the incommensurate systems.

sec.title: Designing fractional order controller based on the proposed CRA methods
sec.p: The following example illustrates the ability of the proposed methods to control fractional order systems with a commensurate order in the range of (0,0.5].
Example 5. Consider a commensurate fractional order system with the following transfer function

The step response of the system indicates an overshoot of 22.5% and a rising time of 3.467 seconds (Figure 10). It is desired to confine the closed-loop step response to maximum 2% overshoot and to have 1.5 seconds rise time. Based on the first proposed method and according to equations (6) and (7), the closed-loop system should have a commensurate order v1=0.8 and the minimum order (n) of 8. Consequently, coefficients of the terms with orders 2.8, 2, 1.2 and 0.4 have to be adjusted to zero. Thus, the desired closed-loop transfer function is

caption.p: The unit step response of system in (51).

sec.p: The initially chosen generalized time constant τi=1seconds results in a step response with a rising time of 2.35 seconds. Therefore, the final generalized time constant is determined as τf=1.5×1/2.35=0.6383seconds (Figure 11).

caption.p: The initial and final designs using the CRA method 1 for Example 5.

sec.p: Assuming d0=1 and using the pattern in equation (5) for characteristic ratios results in the following desired closed-loop transfer function:
To design the RST controller, the following control polynomials are considered:
By using these polynomials, the closed-loop transfer function would be
where
The control parameters are calculated by equating two transfer functions in equations (53) and (55):

To have an idea about applicability of the designed controller, the calculated control signal has been shown in Figure 12. The ratio between the maximum and steady-state amplitudes of this signal is about 5, which is an acceptable value.

caption.p: The control signal obtained based on the first CRA design method.

sec.p: To design the controller based on the CRA method in Section 3.2, one may choose n=7 and employ the characteristic ratios given by equation (21). The design parameters λ and β are tuned by trial and error to reach the design goal (λ=0.02 and β=0.34). This choice of parameters results in a closed-loop step response with about 1.18% overshoot. Considering an initial generalized time constant τi=0.01seconds results in a rise time 2.8198 seconds. Therefore, the final generalized time constant is calculated as τf=0.01×(1.5/2.8198)=0.0053seconds. Figure 13 shows the simulation results.

caption.p: The initial and final designs using the CRA method 2.

sec.p: The desired closed-loop transfer function becomes
Consider the control polynomials as follows
Using these polynomials in RST control structure, the closed-loop transfer function becomes
where
Transfer functions in equations (56) and (58) should be matched term by term. This yields the following control parameters:

Figure 14 shows the control signal in this case. The maximum amplitude of this signal is about 3.5, which is smaller than the corresponding one acquired in the first CRA-based design method. However, the settling time for the control signal is more than its corresponding value obtained in the first method.

caption.p: The control signal obtained based on the second CRA design method.

sec.p: Based on the third CRA-based design method, the desired closed-loop transfer function takes the following form:

Consider the free design parameter in equation (31) as γ=1.11. For the generalized time constant τi=20seconds, the obtained rise time is 3.6138seconds. Thus, according to the time-scaling property, the final generalized time constant would be τf=20×(1.5/3.6138)=8.3015seconds. For these design choices, the resultant desired closed-loop transfer function is
and its step response overshoot is 1.91% (Figure 15).

caption.p: The initial and final designs based on the third CRA method.

sec.p: To determine the control signal, the RST polynomials are considered as
and therefore, the closed-loop transfer function would be
where
Matching similar terms in equations (60) and (62) yields the following control parameters:
In this case the control signal is too large to be implementable in real applications (Figure 16).

caption.p: The control signal obtained based on the third CRA design method.

sec.p: Although the generated control signal in this method is generally large (due to the existing zero), but when the commensurate order is too low, this method requires lesser control parameters in comparison with the other proposed methods.

For the fourth CRA design method, the assumptions of μ=0.035, n=7, and τ=0.0096 seconds results in a closed-loop step response with 1.5 seconds rising time and the allowed overshoot level. The desired closed-loop transfer function is
Use of the following polynomials in the RST control structure
results in the closed-loop transfer function as
where
In order to find the control parameters, transfer functions in equations (63) and (65) should be equated. This results in the following control parameters:

The unit step response of the closed-loop system is depicted in Figure 17. As it is seen the allowable overshoot has been retained. As in the previous case, the maximum amplitude of the control signal is very large in this case, too (Figure 18).

caption.p: The unit step response of system in (63).
The control signal obtained based on the forth CRA design method.

sec.p: One way to reduce the control effort is to decrease the product of the successive characteristic ratios. For example when this product is −2 instead of −3 (note that this choice requires us to consider τ=0.0099seconds to reach the desired rising time), the control effort decreases almost twice (Figure 18). This approach could be utilized to decrease the control effort in the third CRA method as well.
Finally, the CRA based on the approximation model is employed to reach the desired step response. To do so, the transfer function in equation (51) is approximated by the following

where v^ belongs to (0.5,1]. The steady-state gain of the approximating model has taken to be the same as the corresponding one in the original system. The model parameters in equation (66) have been determined by minimizing the cost function defined in equation (50). The coincident frequencies were chosen as 0.01:0.01:100. Solving the defined optimization problem results in the following approximating transfer function.

The relative degree for the original transfer function and the approximating model is almost the same. Figure 19 compares the unit step responses of the original system to the approximating model. The comparison of frequency responses is illustrated in Figure 20. These figures show that the approximating model represents the original system adequately.

caption.p: Comparison between the step responses of the original transfer function in in (51) and the approximating ones in (67) and (68).

sec.p: The other choice for the approximation is to use a four-term model structure. This option results in the following approximating transfer function.

The highest order of the denominator (1.5984) is almost equal to the corresponding one in the original transfer function. The unit step response and Bode diagram of the approximating transfer function in equation (68) are closer to the original responses comparing with the corresponding ones in equation (67) (Figures 19 and 20).

caption.p: Comparison between Bode diagrams of the original transfer function in (51) and the approximating ones in (67) and (68).

sec.p: Consider five terms or more for the denominator is not required since in those cases the commensurate order becomes smaller than half.

Considering the approximating model in equation (67), the desired closed-loop system becomes a four-term transfer function with commensurate order 0.8275. To reach the desired rise time (1.5sec), the generalized time constant is calculated as τ=0.6807sec. This results in the following desired closed-loop transfer function
To obtain the above desired closed-loop system, the following control polynomials are considered in the RST control structure
With the open loop system in equation (67) and RST control structure (Figure 3) having the above polynomials, the following closed-loop transfer function is obtained
By matching the transfer functions in equations (69) and (71), the controller parameters in equation (70) are calculated as r0=0.1409,r1=0.0262,s0=0.8591,s1=0.6149,t0=1.

Figure 21 compares the unit step response of the closed-loop system containing the designed controller with that of the desired one in equation (69). This figure shows the level of accuracy of the approximating model. The maximum amplitude of the control signal is about five times of its steady-state value (Figure 22).

caption.p: Unit step responses of desired and designed closed loop systems.
The control signal obtained by the designed controller.

sec.p: The RST controller could be also designed based on the approximating model in equation (68). This model is slightly more accurate than the one in equation (67) (Figures 19 and 20). In this case, the desired closed-loop transfer function would have six terms. Considering the time-scaling property and determining the final generalized time constant as τ=0.002559seconds, the desired closed-loop transfer function is obtained as
For the following RST polynomials
the closed-loop transfer function is obtained as
By matching the similar terms in equations (72) and (74), the control parameters are obtained as
The unit step responses of the desired closed-loop system in equation (72) and the one obtained by implementing the designed controller coincide with each other almost completely (Figure 23).

caption.p: Unit step responses of the desired and designed closed loop systems.

sec.p: The step response obtained with equation (73) settles to its final value quickly when compared to the corresponding one obtained with equation (72). This results in greater control effort as shown in Figure 24.

caption.p: The control signal obtained by the designed controller.

sec.p: Table 3 summarizes the drawbacks and benefits of the proposed CRA-based control design methods in this paper. The free parameters could be used to adjust the overshoot level. Moreover, there are some other free parameters that could be employed by the designer to manage some additional requirements. For instance, the product of the successive characteristic ratios could be considered as a free parameter to control the maximum amplitude of the control signal. The number of the terms in the approximating method and the parameter λ in the second method could be used to adjust the control signal as well.

caption.p: Comparison among the proposed CRA design methods.

tr.td: difficult to tune parameters, extra control parameters
large control action, slow response settlement
large control action, slow response settlement
needs optimization techniques, the approximation error effect
indirect method, viable control signal, minimum number of control parameters

sec.p: Reducing the number of fractional terms is an important issue in practical implementation of a fractional order controller. In this case fractional derivatives are realized by fractances that are capacitors with fixed derivative action (Sugi and Saito, 1996; Podlunby et al., 2002). Since these elements are still expensive, having less fractional derivative terms in a controller makes its implementation less expensive, and this is why methods with less control parameters are preferred.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Five different CRA methods to design controllers for fractional order systems having commensurate order in (0,0.5] have been presented in this paper. The first method assigns the characteristic ratios indirectly. The main advantage of this method is that the existing pattern for characteristic ratios could be employed for this case as well. But its drawback is that the order of the desired closed-loop transfer function should be increased appropriately. The second method is a direct method with two free parameters that should be adjusted by trial and error. This method requires an increase in the transfer function order. The third method, which uses a desired closed-loop transfer function along with a zero, is appropriate for fractional order systems with small commensurate orders. There is no need to use high order transfer function in this case. However, this method needs a great deal of control effort which could limit its applicability. The fourth method admits use of negative characteristic ratios and could be used only in some applications. The expensive control effort could be seen in this method as well. However, it is possible to adjust the control signal maximum magnitude by using an available free parameter in this design method. The fifth method is based on an approximating model of the system and generally produces suitable results. The only restriction is that this method is not completely analytical and requires some numerical methods to solve the related optimization problem.

Some questions are posed here. Could the CRA-based design methods be applied to control non-minimum phase systems as well? Could the desired closed-loop step response with constraint on control signal be satisfied (by using free parameters in the proposed design approaches)? Answering these questions could be considered as future perspectives in the topics of the present work.
